text: the Pyongyang subway station is a
classic stop on any foreign media trip
to this city with the giant Soviet style
halls and the murals of the ruling
family but as this country prepares to
celebrate its biggest national holiday
and as those celebrations are taking
place amid one of the periodic peaks in
the crisis and tension that often
defines North Korea's relationship with
the outside world it is if nothing else
a chance to ask some of the local people
what they think we should have the
nuclear weapons
if we do not have the nuclear weapons
the the nuclear weapon of another
country will fall on our soil you think
it keeps the country safe it doesn't
matter whether the Americans they make
the situation on the Korean Peninsula it
doesn't matter we feel safe because we
have the great leader Kim Jong
warrantees of course all of these
answers are given under the watchful eye
of our government minders and for them
there is a purpose to all of this the
foreign media are invited to North Korea
to allow it to give its version of
ordinary life here to humanize this
country but there's another purpose too
and that is to give this message of
unyielding defiance and resilience in
the face of international pressure John
Saad worth BBC News Pyongyang
